newsitem.title: ITALY: Fincantieri assembles first ship for Disney.
newsitem.headline: Fincantieri assembles first ship for Disney.

text.p: Italian state-controlled shipbuilder Fincantieri said it has completed the assembly of the two fore and aft sections of the cruise ship "Disney Magic", for Walt Disney Co's Disney Cruise Line.
The ship is the first of two 85,000 gross tonnes, 2,400 passenger capacity sister ships Fincantieri is building for Disney which is entering the cruise industry for the first time.
The "Disney Magic" and the "Disney Wonder" are due to be handed over at the start and at the end of 1998 respectively.
Cruise industry experts estimate that Disney spent more than $300 million to build each ship.

Fincantieri said in a statement that the two sections of the "Disney Magic" were built separately at its Venice Marghera and Ancona shipyards and then welded together at Marghera where fitting-out will be completed.
"This was an exceptional ship's surgical operation that has never been accomplished with another cruise vessel," it said.

The "Disney Magic" construction confirms Fincantieri's leading role among the few world shipyards capable of building large cruise ships, with a market share of over 40 percent in terms of gross tonnage.

Fincantieri said that since the mid-1980s it has won contracts on the world market for 21 cruise vessels -- 10 of which have already been handed over - for an aggregate value of over 11 trillion lire ($6.5 billion).
Its orderbook for the remaining 11 vessels to be built currently totals over 6.5 trillion lire.
Fincantieri made a 1996 group net profit of 50.3 billion lire against 25.2 billion in 1995.

On Saturday April 19, it is due to officially hand over the "Dawn Princess" to Peninsular and Oriental's Princess Cruises at its Monfalcone shipyard near Trieste. The "Dawn Princess" is a sister of the 77,000 tonne "Sun Princess" which was delivered in November 1995.
